nodes.text: Economists' empirical estimates and IAMs (notably DICE) severely underestimate economic damages from climate change and are unsuitable for assessing climate risks or informing policy
Economic damage estimates often ignore climate tipping points or assign them negligible probability
Many economic studies assume only weather-exposed sectors are vulnerable and treat manufacturing, services and government as essentially insulated from climate change
Economists frequently use spatial cross-sectional correlations between current temperature and income as proxies to estimate temporal impacts of global warming
The DICE IAM, because of its Ramsey-based structure, calibration and functional assumptions, cannot generate an economic collapse even under extreme damage specifications
Scientific literature identifies multiple climate tipping elements likely triggerable this century (e.g., Arctic sea-ice, Greenland ice sheet) and tipping cascades that amplify impacts
Including scientifically elicited tipping-point likelihoods in DICE-like models can increase the social cost of carbon by more than a factor of eight and raise estimated damages substantially

Arguments that indoor/controlled activities are immune are flawed because extreme events, uninhabitable climates, biodiversity loss, supply-chain and input disruptions (energy, food, minerals) will impair manufacturing and services

Common methodological approaches in economic damage estimation include enumeration (sectoral summation assuming many sectors unaffected), statistical spatial proxies, CGE models assuming rapid market adaptation, and expert elicitation of mixed experts

Using current spatial temperature-income relationships to predict future global warming impacts is invalid because (a) regional economies reflect historical adaptation and trade linkages, (b) physics of regional variability differs from global change, and (c) novel climate states and extremes will arise

Sensitivity experiments on DICE increasing damage convexity massively raise damages, force corner solutions (immediate full mitigation), produce extreme temporary collapses in consumption and capital-output ratios, yet model numerics still typically return recovery instead of sustained collapse

Peer-review and disciplinary norms in economics (e.g., acceptance of unrealistic domain assumptions as permissible if model 'works') contributed to proliferation of flawed damage estimates and narrow expert communities

Evidence that heat stress thresholds (wet-bulb 35Â°C), reductions in habitable land, and wildfire/flood risks imply much larger economic and habitability impacts than those implied by small-percent GDP damages

Shared datasets, model calibration to the flawed estimates, small close-knit author/referee networks, and methodological dogma caused widespread adoption of underestimated damage functions (e.g., quadratic DICE damages)

DICE structural assumptions (Cobb-Douglas output, full employment, exogenous productivity growth, saddle-path stability) mathematically favor recovery and prevent model-generated economic collapse even under extreme damages

Conclusion: Current economic damage estimates and IAM calibrations (notably DICE, FUND, PAGE) calibrated on them are unreliable and should not be used to evaluate climate risks or form policy; science-based approaches recognizing tipping risks and broader economic exposure should take precedence
